ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Various theories surrounding prison abolition and reform, exposed to the works of great writers, and thought through practical ways to imagine the future of abolition
Reading about abolition both historically and presently and engaging with current abolitionist work.

I learned about the context of mass incarceration in the united states as well as the implications on current economic, social, and political issues today. We also discussed theories of abolition and the main arguments for and against abolition. We discussed abolition as a theoretical framework and also how it applies practically in conjunction with prison reform.
Knowledge on the origins and current day of the prison nation.
I learned about the fundamental structure of mass incarceration and how it is directly related to neoliberalism. I feel more confident engaging in conversations about incarceration and abolition.
Deep insight into the prison industrial complex that is rooted in an understanding of neoliberalism, carceral frameworks, and intersectional understandings of race, gender, and class.

In the first half of the course I gained a breadth of knowledge about America's "Prison Nation," from learning about California's massive prison building project to learning about the functioning of misdemeanor courts to immigration detention to violence against women. The second half of the course exposed me to many of the nuances surrounding abolition and reform that I had not previously considered, as well as multiple abolitionist perspectives.

We need more classes like this! In addition to unpacking the theories behind abolition, we were able to discuss what abolition can actually look like in practice. The class brought up realistic and important questions including: How can we redefine safety? Why is it necessary to move towards community-based models of care and investment, rather than turning to the carceral state? How is the carceral state inherently violent? We were able to unpack how the carceral state operates in collaboration with global capitalism, immigrant policing and deportation, neoliberal reform, and other violent systems of power. Additionally, I was able to work on my writing skills in a variety of ways, which I expand on below.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths- great selection of readings, engaging class discussions, purposeful class layout and syllabus 
Weakness- none
Remarkably good class with an absolutely stellar professor. The topic is so interesting, and his syllabus is perfect. Professor Manning is genuinely incredible.

Strengths: Really cool professor, great, great readings, communication style assingments.
Areas of Improvement: The discussion times were sometimes a bit awkward but that is normal! Maybe also a bit less reading, it was almost impossible to complete the reading from monday to wednesday sometimes.

This course ends up being very student led in a way that is very helpful and insightful for everyone. Professor Manning adds his expertise in a complementary but not overpowering way in class. Another strength is bringing in outside speakers which helps to build a well rounded perspective that brings in community leaders. One weakness is the newsletter as the final project as the goal of it was not clarified from the start and led to some confusions about how we should disseminate it.

Strengths: the course provided a very strong basis for understanding abolition. I feel we covered a large amount of literature. I also enjoyed the guest speakers, it added a very special element to the course where I see the theories we discussed being put into action.

Weaknesses: I think there could have been even more diversity of sources. I appreciate all of the books we read, but it would have been nice to read a few more articles and documentary sources. I also would have liked to focus in on one or two stories where we get to see the impacts of mass incarceration.   I appreciate the unconventional approach to writing assignments, however I wish there was more independent work in the class.
Strengths: Professor Manning! Classroom environment is also full of life, and the readings are incredibly interesting.

Strengths: the breadth of what is covered. I learned about a lot. How abolition is discussed in class. Professor Manning's lectures. The assignments (both the sociological correspondences and the final newsletter) were really engaging and definitely felt meaningful and worthwhile. // Weaknesses: because so much was covered, I felt like I didn't learn in as much depth as I would have liked to. I think I would understand what we were learning better if there was more time dedicated to each topic. Sometimes I wish the culture of class discussions was more accepting to not fully-formed thoughts or opinions (I think this is more of a reflection of the people in the class though, not the class itself)

I appreciated how this class went beyond the typical essay format. Our assignments included writing correspondences with a partner, which I deeply valued because I learned a lot from my peers' personal experiences and thoughts. I also felt I was able to write more freely in the format of a letter to a peer. Other assignments included a submission to a final class "newsletter"the form of this submission could range from an op-ed, personal narrative, literature review, interviews and recaps of local events, and visual/video/artistic presentations. A huge strength of this class was this flexibility in format, emphasizing both traditionally academic and more creative mediums as valid forms of intellectual work. Another assignment was a book review and tour (ie. presenting a reading and leading the class discussion on it), which was done as a group. Again, I learned a lot from working with my peers and learned a lot from their experiences. This was another strength of this class, as it gave us warm and safe space to share our own lives and experiences with the carceral state. There was also no judgment in class discussions, as people were able to debate, question, and express doubts about abolitionism and then discuss them further.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
Yes definitely! No matter your disciplinary interests, I'd recommend any Yale student to take this course. You come to realize how widespread the implications of prisons are. I came into this course relatively unfamiliar with the history of prisons and mass incarceration. After this course, I've been introduced to a number of theorists and scholars like Angela Davis, Ruth Wilson Gilmore, Beth Richie and have a comprehensive understanding of what abolition means. I found myself drawing from course themes in my other seminars. 

Would definitely recommend this course if it's taught under Prof. Manning.
Yes, definitely take this course to learn more about the carceral state and its impact on society. Incredibly useful information and very applicable to a variety of fields.
YES!
Yes! It's definitely been one of my favorite classes of my Yale experience.
Yes! The Professor is really thoughtful and the class is great.
Yes!

Yes, abolition is a very 'trendy' topic right now and I think it is important to fully understand the concept before participating in discussions. It provides the structure and guidance necessary to learn about abolition in a meaningful way.

Yes. I learned so much and Professor Manning is great! There is also a fair degree of freedom and flexibility towards the end of the class so you can really choose to dig into what intrigues you the most about the Prison Nation/abolition.
Yes!

Yes! We need more classes like this! In addition to unpacking the theories behind abolition, we were able to discuss what abolition can actually look like in practice. The class brought up realistic and important questions including: How can we redefine safety? We were able to unpack how the carceral state operates in collaboration with global capitalism, immigrant policing and deportation, neoliberal reform, and other violent systems of power. Additionally, I was able to work on my writing skills in a variety of ways, which I expand on below.
